title: 107_hr3223
content: The Act is titled the "Jicarilla Apache Reservation Rural Water System Act" and its purpose is outlined in Section 2. The "Jicarilla Apache Reservation Rural Water System Act" aims to ensure safe water supply and wastewater systems for residents of the Jicarilla Apache Reservation in New Mexico. It authorizes the Secretary of the Interior to plan, design, and construct these systems in collaboration with the Jicarilla Apache Nation, including service connections to facilities in Dulce and surrounding areas. The Jicarilla Apache Reservation Rural Water System Act authorizes the Secretary of the Interior to collaborate with the Jicarilla Apache Nation to plan, design, and construct water supply and wastewater systems, including service connections to facilities in Dulce and surrounding areas. The Jicarilla Apache Nation is authorized to plan, design, and construct water supply and wastewater systems, with technical assistance from the Bureau of Reclamation. The Nation will assume ownership and responsibility for the system. The Jicarilla Apache Nation is authorized to plan, design, and construct water supply and wastewater systems with technical assistance from the Bureau of Reclamation. The Nation will assume ownership and responsibility for the system. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. The Act defines key terms such as "Act" referring to the Jicarilla Apache Reservation Rural Water System Act, "BIA" as the Bureau of Indian Affairs, "irrigation" as the commercial application of water for agriculture, "Reclamation" as the Bureau of Reclamation, and "Report" as a specific report related to water and wastewater improvements for the Jicarilla Apache Nation. The term "Reservation" refers to the Jicarilla Apache Reservation in New Mexico, including lands held in trust by the United States for the Tribe. The term "Rural Water Supply Project" pertains to water and wastewater facilities serving towns, communities, tribal reservations, and farmsteads. The term "Tribe" refers to the Jicarilla Apache Nation, and the term "State" specifically means the State of New Mexico. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of the Interior, and a "Rural Water Supply Project" is a water and wastewater facility serving various communities and farmsteads. The Jicarilla Apache Reservation Rural Water System is established. The Jicarilla Apache Reservation Rural Water System is established to plan, design, and construct the Rural Water Supply Project in collaboration with the Tribe. The project aims to improve water supply, delivery, and wastewater facilities in Dulce, New Mexico, and surrounding communities for clean, safe, and reliable water services. The project includes facilities for water supply, delivery, and wastewater services for Dulce, Mundo Ranch Development, and surrounding areas on the Reservation, as well as pumping and treatment facilities, distribution, collection, and treatment facilities for the Reservation's needs. The Jicarilla Apache Reservation Rural Water System aims to improve water supply, delivery, and wastewater facilities in Dulce, New Mexico, and surrounding communities. This includes pumping and treatment facilities, distribution, collection, and treatment facilities for the Reservation's needs, as well as necessary property rights and other facilities deemed necessary by the Secretary. The Secretary deems necessary property and property rights for the Reservation, including water supply, economic, public health, and environmental needs. The tribal share of the cost includes designing and initiating construction of wastewater treatment plants, replacing diversion structures, and constructing water treatment facilities. The tribal share of the cost for the Rural Water Supply Project includes designing and initiating construction of the wastewater treatment plant, replacing the diversion structure on the Navajo River, and constructing various water facilities. The Federal share covers the remaining project costs as identified in the Report, with funds also allocated for operation and maintenance. Upon completion of the Rural Water Supply Project, the Tribe will be responsible for operation, maintenance, and replacement costs as outlined in the Act and the Operation, Maintenance, and Replacement Plan in the Report. The Secretary has the authority to enter contracts and promulgate regulations to implement the Act and the Indian Self-Determination Act. Project requirements include the Tribe being responsible for operation, maintenance, and replacement costs after the Rural Water Supply Project is completed. The Secretary will prepare a project plan for the Rural Water Supply Project, including maps and engineering drawings. The Tribe must develop an operation and maintenance plan for setting rates. A construction manager will be selected to assist with planning and construction in consultation with the Tribe. The Secretary will work with the Tribe to establish rates and fees for the Rural Water Supply Project. A construction manager will be selected to assist with planning and construction. A memorandum of agreement will be made for operations and maintenance during and after construction. The Secretary will provide oversight and technical assistance as needed. The Secretary will provide oversight and technical assistance to the Tribe for the Rural Water Supply Project, ensuring construction within the Reservation boundaries and compliance with the Indian Self-Determination Act. The Rural Water Supply Project within the Reservation boundaries will be subject to the Indian Self-Determination Act. The Secretary will provide oversight and report to Congress on the project's progress annually. Title to the project will be held in trust for the Tribe by the United States. SEC. 7. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. Authorized appropriation of $45,000,000 for Rural Water Supply Project planning, design, and construction. Funds can only be used after completion of appraisal investigation, feasibility study, and NEPA requirements. The Secretary and the Tribe completed an appraisal investigation and feasibility study for the Rural Water Supply Project. The Secretary must also ensure that the plan required by section 6(a)(2) is finished before obligating funds for construction. Additionally, funds cannot be used until the National Environmental Policy Act requirements are met. SEC. 8 prohibits the use of funds for irrigation purposes in the Rural Water Supply Project. SEC. 9 addresses water rights. SEC. 9 of the Jicarilla Apache Tribe Water Rights Settlement Act recognizes the Tribe's water rights adjudicated under New Mexico State law. These rights provide water for the municipal water system without impacting other tribal water rights. The Rural Water Supply Project has no new depletions associated with it and will not significantly impact endangered species.
